awd_titl_txt: EAGER-New Search Technique for keV Sterile Neutrinos
awd_abstract_narration:
The nature of dark matter is one of the most important questions in physics today, and the massive sterile neutrino is an excellent candidate. Earlier searches have produced excellent sensitivities for masses between 20 and 300 MeV/c^2; however, the mass range between a few keV/c^2 and one MeV/c^2 is of great interest as candidates for both cold and warm dark matter. A few searches have been made in this mass range; however, the branching ratio sensitivities have only been between 10^-3 and 10^-4, while the mass range below 200 keV/c^2 is almost unexplored. The experiment being planned here is designed to test the effectiveness of the experimental technique to explore this entire region with branching ratio sensitivities on the order of 10^-6. 

The PI is collaborating with the University’s College of Engineering in detector development. The ideal detector geometry at the focus of the Gerholm spectrometer is conical. The available conical detectors are plastic scintillators coupled to avalanche photodiodes. The team will explore the development of a conical solid-state detector with fast response. The PI’s Engineering colleagues have already produced excellent planar silicon carbide (SiC) detectors for x-rays. Together they want to develop techniques to deposit the active detector material on a conical sub-straight to create a high-resolution electron detector with the ideal geometry for the spectrometer. There are many other potential applications for particle detectors deposited on curved surfaces.

If this pilot program is successful in demonstrating that radioactive sources with very small beta-decay branches can be measured with this spectrometer, this technique could be applied in a larger second-generation experiment to reach branching ratios of ~10^-8. The funds awarded will be used to demonstrate the efficacy of a newly developed technique in beta spectroscopy to search for sterile neutrinos with a recently reconfigured high-transmission Gerholm beta spectrometer. The funds will also provide for a data acquisition system, radioactive sources, machine shop services and graduate student support to perform a pilot search.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report 

EAGER: “New Search Technique for keV Sterile Neutrinos.” Federal Award ID: 2134505

            In 1933 CALTECH astronomer Fritz Zwicky analyzed observational data and concluded that the relative motions of the galaxies in the Coma Cluster violated the laws of classical mechanics, unless there was much more mass in the cluster than one observes in stars and dust. The astronomer Vera Rubin observed that velocity of stars in spiral galaxies violate Keppler’s laws of motion, again unless there is much more mass in the galaxies than observed in stars and dust. This strengthened Zwicky’s proposal that there must be some unobserved mass, “Dunkel Materia” or Dark Matter, distributed throughout galaxies and galaxy clusters, and perhaps throughout the universe. The need to add Dark Matter to our models of galaxies and galaxy clusters is now well established. The nature of this material is currently one of the most important problems in astronomy, astrophysics and cosmology. The first terrestrial direct searches for dark matter in the 1980s led to dozens of experiments using a variety of techniques, searching for “Weakly-Interacting Massive Particles,” (WIMPS) that permeate the volume of our galaxy and, in fact, the universe. Knowing that the earth moves through our galaxy at about 200 kilometers per second, a detector on earth should encounter a relative “wind” of WIMPS colliding with the detector material and creating a signal. Even though many detectors of various types have been searching for that signal for 40 years; no confirmed signal has yet been observed. The WIMP has also been searched for at the CERN Laboratory in Geneva using the world’s most powerful accelerator, the Large Hadron Collider. No such candidate particle has been found. Accordingly, the physics community began to search for alternative candidate particles that could be the mysterious Dark Matter. 

In 2017, several groups had revisited the proposal of Scott Dodelson and Lawrence Widrow, who in 1997 published a paper stating, “The simplest model that can accommodate a viable nonbaryonic dark matter candidate is the standard electroweak theory with the addition of a right-handed or sterile neutrino.” Since then, a number of other theoretical groups have revisited and refined this proposal. Over the years, several experimental groups searched for the distortion of the energy spectra of nuclear beta decay that would result from the emission of such a neutrino. The best limit these experiments placed on the probability of emission with a sterile neutrino is about one in a thousand, for neutrinos with masses between roughly one hundredth to about twice an electron mass (mc2= 511 kilovolts). While these results are interesting, it is possible that if such a neutrino exists, the relative rate of its emission in beta decay could be one in a million, or even less. The motivation of this proposal was to investigate another technique to detect a tiny distortion of a beta-decay spectrum that could potentially reach such sensitivities. 

The main task proposed was to create an instrument to demonstrate a method using an ultra-high statistical, as well as, high-resolution technique, rather than only a high-resolution method to apply to beta-decay spectra to search for such neutrinos and to measure-or place limits on-their branching ratios. 

This grant was for two years, but unfortunately, funding began June 2021 when the COVID-19 pandemic restricted activities on campus required to design and produce parts for the project. By early 2023 the campus returned to normal operations. An old, high-transmission electron spectrometer was recovered from storage, and parts to convert it to its new mission were designed and machined. A new turbo high-vacuum pump was acquired and parts to couple it to the spectrometer were fabricated. A graduate student, was supported to assist in the development of the computer-controlled data acquisition system and in designing the data-analysis techniques. An inexpensive surface barrier detector was installed for the initial test operations; the cost of a high-resolution silicon electron detector was until now beyond available funding. The system was finally completed and tested in the summer of 2024.  Beta spectra from the decay of stronthium-90 and yittrium-90 were used to test the instrument. This completed Phase I; the final report to the NSF has been submitted. 

In early 2024 local funding from university sources became available and a high-resolution, lithium-drifted silicon detector was ordered. The cryogenic detector cooling system is being designed and will be installed in the Fall of 2024. At that point Phase II, the collection of high-transmission, high-resolution beta spectra to search for heavy sterile neutrinos will begin. In December 2024, a proposal to fund Phase II, which is a long search, will be submitted to the NSF via the program: Searching for New Physics Beyond the Standard Model Using Precision Measurements (BSM-PM). This project truly fits the definition of a high risk, high pay-off research project.
